speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon, and welcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues at the Federal Reserve and I are dedicated to serving the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do this by steadfastly pursuing the goals that Congress has given us: maximum employment and stable prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re committed to making the best decisions we can based on facts and objective analysis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today we decided to lower the interest rates for the third time this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We took this step to help keep the U.S. economy strong in the face of global developments and to provide some insurance against ongoing risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I will explain shortly, the policy adjustments we have made since last year are providing—and will continue to provide—meaningful support to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We believe that monetary policy is in a good place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The U.S. economy is in its 11th year of expansion, and the baseline outlook remains favorable.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The overall economy is growing at a moderate rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Household spending continues to be strong, supported by a healthy job market, rising incomes, and solid consumer confidence.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In contrast, business investment and exports remain weak, and manufacturing output has declined over the past year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sluggish growth abroad and trade developments have been weighing on those sectors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Looking ahead, we continue to expect the economy to expand at a moderate rate, reflecting solid household spending and supportive financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The job market remains strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate has been near half-century lows for a year and a half.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The pace of job gains has eased this year but has remained solid; we had expected some slowing after last year’s strong pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Participation in the labor force by people in their prime working years has been increasing, and wages have been rising, particularly for lower-paying jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People who live and work in low- and middle-income communities tell us that many who have struggled to find work are now getting opportunities to add new and better October 30, 2019 chapters to their lives.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This underscores for us the importance of sustaining the expansion so that Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the strong job market reaches more of those left behind.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation continues to run below our symmetric 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the 12 months through August, total PCE inflation was 1.4 percent and core inflation was 1.8 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation pressures remain muted, and indicators of longer-term inflation expectations are at the lower end of their historic ranges.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re mindful that continued below-target inflation could lead to an unwelcome downward slide in long-term inflation expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: However, against the backdrop of a strong economy and supportive monetary policy, we expect inflation will rise to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Overall, we continue to see sustained expansion of economic activity, a strong labor market, and inflation near our symmetric 2 percent objective as most likely.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While this has been our outlook for quite some time, our views about the path of interest rates that will best achieve these outcomes have changed significantly over the past year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, weakness in global growth and trade developments have weighed on the economy and pose ongoing risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These factors, in conjunction with muted inflation pressures, have led us to lower our assessment of the appropriate level of the federal funds rate over the past year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In both July and September, we reduced the target rate [range] for the federal funds rate by ¼ percentage point, and we did so again today, bringing the range to 1½ to 1¾ percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The policy adjustments we’ve made to date will continue to provide significant support for the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since monetary policy operates with a lag, the full effects of these adjustments on economic growth, the job market, and inflation will be realized over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see the current stance of monetary policy as likely to remain appropriate as long as incoming information about the economy remains broadly consistent with our outlook of moderate economic growth, a strong labor market, and inflation near our symmetric 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We believe monetary policy October 30, 2019 is in a good place to achieve these outcomes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Looking ahead, we’ll be monitoring the effects of Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL our policy actions, along with other information bearing on the outlook, as we assess the appropriate path of the target range for the fed funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, if developments emerge that cause a material reassessment of our outlook, we would respond accordingly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Policy is not on a preset course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let me end with a few words about our technical monetary policy operations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In January, we made the key decision to continue to implement monetary policy in an ample-reserves regime.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In that operating framework, we control the federal funds rate primarily by setting our administered rates, not through frequent interventions to actively manage the supply of reserves.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the transition to the efficient and effective level of reserves in this regime, we slowed the gradual decline in our balance sheet in March and we stopped it in July.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In response to the funding pressures in money markets that emerged in mid-September, we concluded that it would be appropriate to maintain, over a time—over time, a level of reserve balances at or above the level that prevailed in early September of this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To achieve this ample level, we announced on October 11 that we would purchase Treasury bills at least into the second quarter of next year as well as continue temporary open market operations at least through January.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These actions are purely technical measures to support the effective implementation of monetary policy as we continue to learn about the appropriate level of reserves.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They do not represent a change in the stance of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, our Treasury bill purchases should not be confused with the large-scale asset purchase programs that we deployed after the financial crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In those programs, we purchased longer-term securities to put downward pressure on longer-term interest rates and ease broader financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In contrast, October 30, 2019 increasing the supply of reserves by purchasing Treasury bills only alters the mix of short-term Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL assets held by the public and should not materially affect demand and supply for longer-term securities or financial conditions more broadly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will be happy to take your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So what we’ve said, to repeat, is that we see the current stance of policy as “likely to remain appropriate as long as incoming information about the economy remains broadly consistent with our outlook.” And we say that, really, because both of the performance of the economy and the stance of policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The performance of the economy has been—particularly the household sector—has been strong, has been resilient, with low unemployment, attractive levels of job creation, wages moving up, labor force participation moving up, household confidence, and solid gains in many measures of consumer spending.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The manufacturing sector, particularly manufacturing, and also investment and exports have been weaker.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, overall, we’ve seen moderate growth, a strong labor market, inflation moving up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see the outlook as for more of the same.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also see the risks to the outlook as perhaps having moved in a positive direction over the course of this intermeeting period, although, some remain—some things remain to be seen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Turning to policy, we’ve moved the stance of policy over the course of the year to a more accommodative stance, and, after the cuts at the last three meetings, the federal funds rate is now October 30, 2019 in a range between 1½ and 1¾ percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We feel that policy is well positioned to support the Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL outlook that I described.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you asked what it would take, you know, to move, and, as I mentioned, we’re going to be watching all factors, And if developments emerge that cause a material reassessment of our outlook, we would respond accordingly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that’s what it would take: a material reassessment of our outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll be looking at a full range of data about the economy and about the risks to the outlook, and I’ve given you a sense of what our outlook is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s for moderate growth, a strong labor market, and inflation near our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If something happens to cause us to materially reassess that outlook, that’s what would cause us to change our views on the appropriate stance of policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in terms of risks, what I was referring to there—the principal risks that we’ve been monitoring have been, really, slowing global growth and trade policy developments as well as muted inflation pressure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I was really referring there to trade developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have that phase-one potential agreement with China, which, if signed and put into effect, could have the effect of reducing trade tensions and reducing uncertainty, and that would bode well, we think, for business confidence and perhaps activity over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that has October 30, 2019 the potential for being an improvement in the risk picture.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Brexit, I would say, as well—it Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL appears that the risk of a no-deal Brexit seems to have materially declined.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think on both situations there’s plenty of risk left, but I’d have to say that the risks seem to have subsided.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You asked about business investment, and that’s right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Business investment has been weak, and today’s reading was weak as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it was broad across equipment and other parts of—all parts of business fixed investment were weak.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s consistent with what we’ve seen, but that’s the economy we’ve had this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we’ve had is an economy where the consumer is really driving growth, and, you know, personal consumption expenditures were almost 3 percent in this quarter—in this first reading for the quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, overall, we see the economy as having been resilient to the—you know, the winds that have been blowing this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes, so that is a risk.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s a risk that we’ve been monitoring, but we don’t see it yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t see rising initial claims or layoffs or anything like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the risk you mention of the weakness in the manufacturing—in export investment, business investment, parts of the economy getting into the consumer side of the economy, we really don’t see that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we continue to see is good job creation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Unemployment has declined again, and the household survey is now at a 50-year low—has been, you know, very close to 50-year lows for 18 months now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s very positive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The consumer-facing companies that we talk to in our vast network of contacts report, you know, that consumers are doing well and are focused on, October 30, 2019 you know, the good job market and rising incomes, and that’s their principle focus.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that is the Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL thing that’s pushing the economy forward, and it doesn’t seem to have been affected so far by weakness in the other areas.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the reason why we raised interest rates is because—generally is because we see inflation as moving up—or, in danger of moving up significantly, and we really don’t see that now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation moved down in the first quarter of this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We thought that that was due, to some extent, to idiosyncratic or transient factors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That turns out to have been the case, so it’s moved back up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it seems to be settling in below 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we really don’t see that risk.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And inflation expectations have also kind of moved down and sideways—both surveys and market based over the course of this—of, really, the recent months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we think that inflation expectations are very important in driving actual inflation, and we’re strongly committed to achieving our 2 percent inflation objective on a symmetric basis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think it’s essential that we do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re not thinking about raising rates right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There obviously will be times in the future where that will be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we’re really thinking now is that our current stance October 30, 2019 of policy is appropriate and will remain so as long as the outlook is broadly in keeping with our Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we think that the current stance of policy is likely to remain appropriate—likely to remain appropriate—as long as incoming information about the economy is broadly consistent with our outlook, which is a positive one of moderate economic growth, strong labor market, and inflation moving close to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s—so that’s what we’re saying about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also say, of course, if developments emerge that cause a material reassessment of that outlook, we would respond accordingly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s really how we’re thinking about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I can’t point to one data point or one thing that would change our minds.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It really—it would be a reassessment of—a material reassessment of our overall outlook, which is what I described.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, there’s—there’s a lot of, you know, practice and science and history, in terms of how much you put in the actual postmeeting statement as opposed to what we say in the press conference statement.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a—you know, it’s a judgment call.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I’m saying it now, so— STEVE LIESMAN.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as I mentioned, we do think that inflation expectations are—they’re quite essential, quite central in our framework of how we think about inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We need them to be anchored in a level—at a level that’s consistent with our symmetric 2 percent inflation goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think that we need to conduct policy in a way that supports that outcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what we’re doing now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re also, as part of our review, looking at potential innovations, changes to the way we think about things, changes to the framework that would lead us—that would be more supportive of achieving inflation on a 2 percent—on a symmetric 2 percent basis over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s at the very heart of what we’re doing in the review.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s too early to be announcing decisions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We haven’t made them yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we’re in the middle of thinking about ways that we can make that symmetric 2 percent inflation objective more credible by achieving symmetric 2 percent inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it comes down to using your policy tools to achieve 2 percent inflation, and that is the—that is the thing that must happen for credibility in this area.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re committed to doing that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re in the middle—we’re really quite in the middle of it now, and my thinking is still that it will run into the middle of next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These are—you know, these changes to monetary policy frameworks happen—they don’t happen really quickly, let’s say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation targeting took many years to evolve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think we’ll take many years here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we’ll wrap it up around the middle of next year, would be my guess.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I have some confidence in that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Rate hikes for next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would just say that a—if we were to have a sustained reduction in trade tensions—broad reduction in trade tensions and a resolution of these uncertainties, that would bode well for business sentiment, which is—trade uncertainty’s been weighing on business sentiment, in our judgment, in the judgment of many analysts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, October 30, 2019 ultimately, it could affect activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t expect that the effects on activity or confidence Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL would be immediate, or—would there be immediate effects in economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think it would take some time after the recent things, but I do think it would be quite positive over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You come back to the question of raising rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s really about inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you know, we haven’t yet—we just touched 2 percent core inflation, to pick one measure—just touched it for a few months, and then we’ve fallen back.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think we would need to see a really significant move up in inflation that’s persistent before we would consider raising rates to address inflation concerns.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I think we’re doing that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, I think we’re keeping—I think we’ve made very substantial adjustments to policy over the course of this year, if you think about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We entered the year expecting some further rate increases, we went to “patient,” now we’ve done three rate cuts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a very substantial shift, and the effects of it will be felt over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we feel like those shifts are appropriate to support exactly the outcomes you’re talking about, which are a continuing strong labor market, continued strong job creation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, no.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It was—so we’ve said it was about three things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s been about the slowing global economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You have a synchronized slowdown in economic activity around the globe.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s been building for just about 18 months now, and that’s having an effect on U.S. activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s part of the weakness in manufacturing, export, and business investment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve had trade policy uncertainty, which we think also has been weighing on activity and investment and sentiment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ve had inflation, which—we’ve called out the risk of inflation running persistently below 2 percent as a risk that we needed to address.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ve been doing it to address all of those things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say, the gains in the labor market have been great to see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s particularly the fact that people at the lower end of wages have been getting most of the benefit of most of the wage gains in the last couple of years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s a great thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know from our Fed Listens events that we’ve been hearing from people who live and work in low- and moderate-income communities that this is the best labor market they’ve seen in their lifetime, things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, that there’s also—there’s still so many people who are, you know, still not in the labor market yet, and that—there’s just a lot more good that can be done there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the same time, we have to think about the whole economy, and—but, yes, those gains are very positive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do call them out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They are a reason for us to want to extend the expansion, and that’s something we’re committed to doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, on the “how long,” what we’ve said is that we expect bill purchases to continue at least into the second quarter of next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ve said that temporary open market operations we expect to continue, I think, at least until the end of January, I believe.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes, through January.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the causes, so there’s a lot of forensic work going on by us and by market participants and all kinds of analysts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, one thing is that we think we need reserves to be back up to the level—the minimum level of reserves that we can have during the various fluctuations that you see with reserves is something like $1.45 trillion or a little higher, and that’s the level in early September.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re going to be adding reserves to get back to that place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s one thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are also—it may be—one thing that was surprising about the episode was that liquidity didn’t seem to flow as one might have expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We had surveyed the banks carefully about what was their lowest comfortable level of reserves, and many banks that were well above that level did not take that excess cash and invest it in the repo market at much higher rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They just—they didn’t do that, and so the question is why.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re looking at those.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those are not things that can happen that can really address the situation in the short term, but those are a range of things that we’re looking at as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Honestly, it’s really the—there isn’t any one factor.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s really the whole range of economic data and also what we see as—about our stance of policy, which we believe is the appropriate stance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s really both of those things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, if you look at the performance of the economy through this, the consumer sector has been quite resilient.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Witness today’s GDP report.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s just—again, all the things I went through earlier suggest that that sector continues to be strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We know that the manufacturing, investment, trade, export sector has been weak.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That continues, but nonetheless, overall, we’ve got an economy that is showing moderate growth, and we think that today’s setting—we’re now at 1.5 to 1.75 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That is, we believe, an accommodative level and a level that will support that outlook that we have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we don’t see any evidence of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we see is—what we see is that the consumer sector continues strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, low initial claims.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s all—the data we monitor, obviously, is a very broad range of data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also see now, I think, more clearly the effects of more accommodative monetary policy on various kinds of consumer activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re seeing strong durable goods sales.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re seeing housing now contributing to growth for the first time in a while—two-tenths, I think, this quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you’re seeing retail sales—the retail October 30, 2019 sales number, the PCE number, as I mentioned, in today’s release was 2.9 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL good.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think, more broadly, monetary policy is also supporting household spending and home buying by keeping the labor market strong, keeping workers’ incomes rising, and keeping consumer confidence at high levels, where it currently is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I think monetary policy works through the channels that we understand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the effects are clear in what we think of as the interest-rate-sensitive sectors, which are the ones—some of the ones that I mentioned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think it’s—I think interest rates are a factor in business investment, but I don’t believe they’re the main factor and main driver.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think, you know, what one would like to see for—to support greater manufacturing activity, business investment, and exports would be a global recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, there’s a lot of monetary policy accommodation and some fiscal accommodation, maybe, in the global economy now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Not here, but perhaps elsewhere.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that should turn—that should support growth in the global economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, resolution of our trade issues would contribute to that over time as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think—we think that Fed Listens has been a great success for us, and I’m sure we will repeat it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In fact, I would imagine that this entire monetary policy review will become institutionalized and be done every few years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say this: In the Beige Book, we talk to educational institutions, health-care institutions, community groups, labor groups—it’s not just businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, all of those groups are also represented on the boards of our regional banks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also meet quite regularly at the Board with representatives of low- and moderate-income communities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we’re—we’re very conscious of—you know, that we represent all Americans, and we need to hear all of their perspectives.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s why we—you know, we talk about how low the unemployment rate is, the aggregate unemployment, but we also talk about groups that haven’t experienced that yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we’re—we try to remind ourselves that we serve everybody.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that is—our outlook overall is for moderate growth of around 2 percent, which is pretty close to trend.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s our outlook: could be better, could be worse.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, it’s—you never say you’ve achieved it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that’s our outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we feel like our current stance of policy is appropriate as long as that remains broadly our outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think this seems to be the right movement.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can see that we had our usual range of perspectives, range of views.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, in the end, we had a strong vote in favor of this action.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I strongly believe it’s the right action.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I strongly believe that the actions we’ve taken over the course of this year have been the right things to do for this economy and are supporting economic growth and will do so in the future.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So— GREG ROBB.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Greg Robb from MarketWatch.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Chairman Powell, it seems that the differences all across the country—that different regions are reacting differently to the China trade, and some regions are much weaker than others.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s this urban versus rural divide, the coasts versus the middle of the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, it’s—monetary policy is famously a blunt instrument.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we can’t—obviously, we can’t raise interest rates some place and lower them other places.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we’re very conscious.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The first thing to know is to understand that, that—and we’ve called that out, as you, I’m sure, know, in one of our recent Monetary Policy Reports to Congress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The sort of rural–urban disparities in—you know, in employment, in growth, in all kinds of things, in health outcomes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, it’s a big and growing difference—set of differences.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t really have, you know, the tools to address that, but we call things out that are important to our economy that we may not be—that we might have—may not have the right tools to best address October 30, 2019 them, but we call them out because, you know, we’re spending all of our time with the economy, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL and those are issues that maybe have to be addressed by legislatures and, you know, by—at the national level and at the state level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m not asking Congress to do anything right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I sometimes have noted that it would be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let me put it this way: We do what we do, which is, we’re assigned a job, which is maximum employment and stable prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do financial stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do bank regulation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The U.S. economy faces significant longer-term challenges around potential growth, around labor force participation, around disparities of income and wealth, around all kinds of things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And those are issues for Congress, and they’re not issues for us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But if you really want the U.S. economy to be all it can be and raise the potential growth rate of the United States, you need—you need proper monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, really, it isn’t monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Really, it’s fiscal policy that supports, you know, inclusive growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes, I know, that’s—I wouldn’t—that’s not how I would characterize it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would just—I noted that it may be that there’s been progress there toward— October 30, 2019 away from bad outcomes and confrontational outcomes, and it seems like there’s the makings of Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL a possible settlement there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I didn’t say we’re baking that in or anything, but I’m just noting that that’s the case.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As with Brexit—it’s still quite uncertain what will be the result of the election and what the ultimate result will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would say that the tail risk of a nonnegotiated no-deal Brexit seems to have decreased, just as I would say that the situation in our trade negotiations with China seems to have taken a step closer to resolution.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s all I’m saying.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, not for us to say what the appropriate labor arrangements will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will just say, on the General Motors strike, it’s—it’s likely to have taken away a couple of tenths of growth this quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s likely to come back, maybe, over the first half of next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think it’s good to see it settled.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I’m not going to comment on what the appropriate labor arrangements are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s a little bit far afield from our task here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wrote it down, I can’t— PAUL KIERNAN.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sorry—if policy is accommodative right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Ah, yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you look at where the federal funds rate is trading, it should be in the middle of, or maybe the lower half of, the range of 150 to 175.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that means the real rate is probably modestly below zero.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think my own sense would be that that’s somewhat accommodative policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say, though, that there’s a range of plausible estimates of what the neutral rate of interest is, and I think many of those who make such estimates have moved their estimate down over the course of many years, and that process continues.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, nonetheless, that seems to me to be very likely to be an accommodative stance of policy, and an appropriate stance, given the situation we’re in with continuing downside risks and—that I mentioned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So— JEAN YUNG.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Hi.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Jean Yung from Market News.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wanted to ask about financial stability risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Recently, the IMF and some other global policymakers have been expressing October 30, 2019 concerns over the high level of risky corporate debt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we monitor financial stability risks very carefully all of the time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s what we do since the financial crisis, as I’ve mentioned before.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Currently, we don’t see large imbalances.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This long expansion is notable for the lack of large financial imbalances like the ones we’ve seen certainly before the crisis happened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we have a four-part framework, I’ll quickly mention.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The first is leverage in the financial system, which is low by historical standards.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The second is funding risk, which is the risk of runnable funding, and that risk is also quite low for banks but also for, you know, the nonbanking financial sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at asset prices, we see some high asset prices but not broadly across a range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t see bubbles and that kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that leaves the fourth, which is leverage in the nonfinancial sector, and that’s households and businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So with households, again, we don’t see leverage.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see them actually getting in very good shape financially in the aggregate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Obviously, plenty of households are not in great shape financially, but in the aggregate, the household sector is in a very good place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That leaves businesses, which is where the issue has been.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Leverage among corporations and other forms of business, private businesses, is historically high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve been monitoring it carefully and taking appropriate steps.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s what I would say, but it’s—corporate debt is one part of a larger part of our framework, and it is something that we’re paying quite a bit of attention to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s been part of the last couple of Shared National Credit exams, and we’ve been monitoring it carefully and taking appropriate action.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re—I think, again, I think the most important basic thing is to get the level of reserves back up so that—reserves move up and down with some volatility.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t want them to move below the level they were at in the beginning of September, which is, again, between $1.45 and $1.5 trillion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s the main thing, that’s the first thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re on a path to do that, between our temporary open market operations and also our bill purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition to that—in addition to that, we’re looking at—there are—it’s a big, complicated marketplace, and there was the—one of the surprises, as I mentioned, was that banks that had told us that their lowest comfortable level of reserves was here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They were well above that, and yet they didn’t deploy that liquidity when there seemed to be great opportunities to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That didn’t happen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so, we’re doing careful analysis of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think that’s where this goes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think where it may go, though, is to look at, for example, intraday liquidity, which used to be a common thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It used to be a common thing for banks to have intraday liquidity from the Fed, what are called “daylight overdrafts.” That’s something we can look at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Also, there are just a few technical things that we can look at that would perhaps make the liquidity that we have—which we think is ample in the financial system—move more freely and be more liquid, if you will.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And those are things we would do, but only if we can do it without compromising safety or soundness or financial stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we—we, of course, have watched the situation in Japan and now the situation in Europe, and we—we note that there are significant disinflationary pressures around the world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we don’t think we’re exempt from those.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, of course, if you look at our current inflation performance, it hasn’t been anything like what we’ve seen in those other places.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we don’t think—again, we don’t think we’re exempt from those pressures, and we are, therefore, strongly committed to having inflation expectations anchored at the level that is consistent with the symmetric 2 percent inflation objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what we’re committed to, and we’ll use our tools to achieve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we take—we take the risk very seriously.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not—the risk isn’t that inflation might run a couple tenths below 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The risk is that what we’ve seen is other economies getting on a disinflationary path, that it’s been very hard for them to get off.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Once inflation expectations start sliding down, inflation moves down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You have less—interest rates move down as well, because there’s an inflation component in interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we think that the right thing to do is to do what we can now to hold and really move inflation expectations up so that they’re squarely and firmly anchored at a level that’s consistent with 2 percent inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, it’s a—it’s an issue, but it’s not an issue that we’re currently working on and—or reaching a decision on or anything like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The question of the longer-run maturity composition of the balance sheet is a—is a big one, and it’s one we’ll return to over time, but not—not imminently.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I’m going to maintain my longtime practice of not—not commenting on anything any elected official would say, but thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks very much.
